title: spec: Type assertions
body:
In the "Type assertions" section, there is an example listed as following:

	type I interface { m() }
	var y I
	s := y.(string)        // illegal: string does not implement I (missing method m)
	r := y.(io.Reader)     // r has type io.Reader and y must implement both I and io.Reader

The comment for the last line is weird. y is a value, how values can implement interfaces?

And here, using io.Reader as a demo is not good, for io.Reader has no m method.
